questions.text: Which nerve is thickened in the following image of a patient with Hansen's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Great Auricular Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • Hansen's disease, also known as leprosy, is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, primarily affecting the skin, mucous membranes, and peripheral nerves. The thickening of nerves is a characteristic feature of this disease.

  • Great auricular nerve arises from ventral rami of C2 C3 of cervical plexus, lies over the posterior triangle of neck. It accompanies upper half of external jugular vein.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. These nerves arise from the cervical plexus and provide sensory innervation to the skin of the upper chest and shoulder area. While they can be affected in Hansen's disease, they are not typically noted for being specifically thickened in this condition.

 

Option B. This nerve arises from the brachial plexus and innervates certain muscles in the back, such as the rhomboid major and minor. Involvement of this nerve in Hansen's disease is less common and it is not known for thickening in the disease.

 

Option D. Also known as the cutaneous cervical nerve, it arises from the cervical plexus and supplies the skin of the anterior neck. Like the supraclavicular nerves, it can be involved in Hansen's disease but is not particularly noted for thickening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve, arising from the cervical plexus, provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, mastoid process, and the back of the ear. In Hansen's disease, this nerve is commonly affected and can become noticeably thickened. It is often used as a clinical sign in the diagnosis of leprosy.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 198

questions.text: The following picture exhibit which cranial nerve palsy:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) VI

 

Option D:

 

  • The condition shown in the above image is abducens nerve palsy.
  • The extraocular muscles are supplied by III cranial nerve, except SO4 & LR-6 (Superior oblique supplied by IV cranial nerve & Lateral rectus supplied by VI cranial nerve)
  • These cranial nerves emerge from the brainstem and directly innervate the respective muscles to control eye movements, including convergence, elevation, depression, and lateral and medial movements. Dysfunction in any of these nerves can lead to specific types of eye movement abnormalities.

 

 

1. Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): This nerve innervates the majority of the extraocular muscles, including:

 

  • Superior rectus: elevates the eye.
  • Medial rectus: moves the eye medially (towards the nose).
  • Inferior rectus: depresses the eye.
  • Inferior oblique: elevates and extorts (rotates laterally) the eye.
  • Levator palpebrae superioris: raises the upper eyelid (not an extraocular muscle but related to eye movement).

 

2. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which depresses, intorts (rotates medially), and abducts the eye.

 

3. Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally, away from the nose).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. III nerve palsy will result in ptosis, external squint, dilated pupil, loss of accommodation reflex.

 

Option B. Facial nerve: Facial nerve supplies the muscles of face. Injury to it leads to facial palsy.

 

Option C. Trochlear nerve: it supplies the superior oblique muscle of eye.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Abducens nerve palsy causes inability to deviate the eyeball laterally due to paralysis of the rectus muscle.
  • Abducens nerve enters orbit through the intermediate compartment of superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve emerges from pons and passes through the intermediate compartment of superior oblique fissure and innervates which of the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Option A:

 

  • Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve arises from lower pons, emerges at pontomedullary junction. Injury to it will cause lateral gaze palsy.

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

  1. Lateral Rectus
  2. Superior Rectus
  3. Superior Oblique Muscle
  4. Medial Rectus

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Superior rectus, innervated by upper division of Oculomotor nerve.

 

Option C. Superior oblique muscle-lies along junction of roof with medial wall, above medial rectus innervated by Trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Medial rectus innervated by lower division of Oculomotor nerve which also supplies inferior rectus and inferior oblique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lateral rectus: Abducens nerve arises from lower pons, emerges at pontomedullary junction. Injury to it will cause lateral gaze palsy.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th edition pg 256

choices.text: Related to posteroinferior angle of Masseter
Winds around the Ramus of the Mandible upward & forward
Facial Artery crosses Superficial to it
It is the lowermost branch of Facial Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pointed structure in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial Artery crosses Superficial to it

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is the Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the muscles of the lower lip and chin, playing a crucial role in facial expression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Related to posteroinferior angle of masseter: This statement is incorrect. The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve does not relate directly to the posteroinferior angle of the masseter muscle. Instead, it runs in the facial region, below the mandible, and is more closely associated with the lower border of the mandible rather than the masseter muscle.

 

Option B. This statement is incorrect. The marginal mandibular branch does not wind around the ramus of the mandible upward and forward. Instead, it runs near the lower border of the mandible. It's the facial nerve's branches that emerge from the stylomastoid foramen and give off various branches, including the marginal mandibular branch, which runs horizontally forward beneath the lower border of the mandible.

 

Option D. While the marginal mandibular branch is one of the lower branches of the facial nerve, which innervates the platysma muscle. The marginal mandibular branch, however, is the lowest branch that controls the muscles affecting the lips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial artery can cross superficial to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve. This anatomical relationship is significant, especially during surgical procedures in the neck and lower face, as it poses a risk for nerve damage if not properly identified.

 

Facial vein also crosses superficial to it.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Glossopharyngeal Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 397

choices.text: Absent Corneal Reflex

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be present in the paralysis of the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is orbicularis oculi.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lacrimal part of orbicularis oculi aids in drainage of lacrimal fluid via lacrimal sac into nasolacrimal duct. Paralysis of which might result in spillage of tears/epiphora

 

Option B. Orbital part of orbicularis oculi will cause tight closure of eyelids, palpebral part gentle closure of eyelids. Paralysis will lead to inability to close eyes and thereby corneal ulceration.

 

Option D. The afferent limb of corneal reflex -ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve, the efferent limb includes facial nerve that innervates orbicularis oculi.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • paralysis of orbicularis oculi cause inability to close the eye.
  • Paralysis of levator palpebrae superioris only will cause ptosis

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck,Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 80

choices.text: Lesser Petrosal Nerve
Greater Petrosal Nerve
Deep Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Greater Petrosal Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • Greater petrosal nerve arises from the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chorda tympani nerve arises from facial nerves 6mm above stylomastoid foramen. It conveys preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the submandibular and sublingual salivary gland. It also conveys taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue.

 

Option B: Lesser petrosal nerve arises from the tympanic plexus formed by the tympanic branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve and carries preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres for parotid gland.

 

Option D: Deep petrosal nerve is formed by the sympathetic plexus that surrounds the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greater petrosal nerve arises from the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve.
  • It conveys preganglionic secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal glands, glands of nasal mucosa and soft palate.
  • It also conveys a taste sensation from the soft palate.

choices.text: Loss of Lacrimation
Parotid Gland Fysfunction
Loss of Taste Sensation from Anterior 2/3 of Tongue

questions.text: What would be the consequence of damaging the nerve located medial to the structure indicated by the blue arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loss of Taste Sensation from Anterior 2/3 of Tongue

 

Option D:

 

  • The pointed structure is the spine of sphenoid. The nerve related medially to the spine of sphenoid is the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Injury to facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion will result in loss of lacrimation.

 

Option B: Injury to glossopharyngeal nerve/auriculotemporal branch of mandibular nerve will result in parotid gland dysfunction.

 

Option C:  Injury to nerve to stapedius, a branch from facial nerve will result in hyperacusis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spine of sphenoid is situated close to foramen spinosum. It is medially related to the cartilaginous part of auditory tube and chorda tympani nerve and laterally auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Chorda tympani carries a taste sensation from anterior 2/3 tongue.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 396

choices.text: 1, 3, 7, 4, 2, 6, 8, 5

questions.text:
Sequential arrangement of secretomotor pathway to lacrimal gland:

 

  1. Pons
  2. Nerve of pterygoid canal
  3. Geniculate ganglion
  4. Nervus intermedius
  5. Lacrimal nerve
  6. Greater petrosal nerve
  7. Pterygopalatine ganglion
  8. Zygomaticotemporal nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 6, 2, 7, 8, 5

 

Explanation:

 

Secretomotor pathway of lacrimal gland

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secretomotor pathway of the lacrimal gland, which controls tear production, is a complex neural pathway involving both autonomic and sensory nerves.

 

  • Origin: The secretomotor pathway for the lacrimal gland originates in the lacrimatory nucleus located in the pontine tegmentum of the brainstem.
  • Parasympathetic Pathway: Preganglionic Neurons, the pathway begins with the preganglionic parasympathetic neurons in the superior salivatory nucleus. These neurons send their axons via the facial nerve.
  • Greater Petrosal Nerve: The fibers then branch off from the facial nerve to form the greater petrosal nerve, which carries these parasympathetic fibers.
  • Pterygopalatine Ganglion: The fibers from the greater petrosal nerve synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion, located in the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Postganglionic Neurons: From the pterygopalatine ganglion, the postganglionic parasympathetic fibers join the branches of the maxillary nerve and reach the lacrimal gland.
  • Sympathetic Pathway: Though the primary control of lacrimal secretion is parasympathetic, there is also a sympathetic innervation. Sympathetic fibers originate in the superior cervical ganglion and follow a pathway along the internal carotid artery, eventually joining the parasympathetic pathway to the lacrimal gland. Sympathetic innervation primarily modulates the blood flow to the gland rather than directly stimulating secretion.
  • Sensory Pathway: Sensory innervation to the lacrimal gland is provided by the lacrimal nerve, a branch of the ophthalmic nerve. This is not directly involved in tear secretion but can influence it reflexively in response to sensory stimuli.
  • Reflex Arc: The lacrimal reflex arc is important in tear production. Sensory input from the cornea and conjunctiva can trigger a reflex increase in tear production via the parasympathetic pathway. Emotional stimuli can also influence this pathway, leading to increased tear production during emotional states.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 76

choices.text: Deep Petrosal Nerve
Lesser Petrosal Nerve
Greater Petrosal Nerve
External Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is a Branch of Facial Nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Greater Petrosal Nerve

 

Option C: The greater petrosal nerve arises from geniculate ganglion of facial nerve and conveys preganglionic secretomotor fibres to lacrimal gland and glands of nasal mucus membrane and soft palate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Deep petrosal nerve arises from the sympathetic plexus around the internal carotid artery, it joins with the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal.

 

Option B: Lesser petrosal nerve – the tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve forms a plexus beneath the promontory and some of the fibres of the plexus conveying preganglionic secretomotor fibres for parotid gland leave tympanic cavity as lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Option D: External petrosal nerve carries sympathetic fibres from the sympathetic plexus around middle meningeal artery coursing extradurally laterally to the greater and lesser petrosal nerves on the petrous ridge’s anterior surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater petrosal nerve is indeed related to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The greater petrosal nerve carries parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that originate in the superior salivatory nucleus of the brainstem. These fibers travel through the facial nerve and exit via the geniculate ganglion. From there, they join the greater petrosal nerve, which then synapses in the pterygopalatine ganglion. The postganglionic fibers from the pterygopalatine ganglion go on to innervate several structures in the head, including the lacrimal gland (for tear production), the nasal glands (for mucus production), and the palatal and pharyngeal glands (for secretion). This parasympathetic pathway is involved in controlling various secretory functions in the head and is associated with the facial nerve through the greater petrosal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 395

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of double vision and difficulty walking, especially when descending stairs or walking on uneven ground. He notes that his symptoms seem to worsen throughout the day. Physical examination reveals a limitation in downward gaze and adduction in the right eye, along with a head tilt towards the left shoulder. There are no other neurological deficits noted. Based on the patient's symptoms, which of the following cranial nerves is most likely not involved in carrying parasympathetic fibers and is associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV

 

Option A:

 

  • The patient's symptoms are suggestive of a condition known as trochlear nerve palsy, which affects the cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve).
  • The trochlear nerve is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle, which helps in downward gaze and intorsion of the eye.
  • The hallmark sign of trochlear nerve palsy is difficulty in looking down, especially noticeable when walking downstairs or on uneven surfaces, leading to a compensatory head tilt towards the opposite shoulder to maintain binocular vision and minimize diplopia.
  • Unlike cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VII (facial), and IX (glossopharyngeal) which carry parasympathetic fibers and are involved in various functions such as eye movements, facial expressions, and salivation/swallowing respectively, the trochlear nerve does not carry parasympathetic fibers and is solely motor in function.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres passing through facial nerve innervates submandibular, sublingual salivary gland, lacrimal gland and glands of soft palate and nasal mucosa.

 

Option C: The preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres passing through Oculomotor nerve innervates ciliary, sphincter pupillae muscles.

 

Option D: The preganglionic parasympathetic secretomotor fibres passing through Glossopharyngeal nerve innervates parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trochlear nerve is purely motor and innervates superior oblique muscle.
  • The trochlear nerve, also known as cranial nerve IV (CN IV), does not carry parasympathetic fibers. It is a motor nerve that innervates a single muscle: the superior oblique muscle of the eye. This muscle is responsible for downward and outward movements of the eyeball.
  • The trochlear nerve is unique among cranial nerves for several reasons:
    • It is the smallest cranial nerve in terms of the number of axons it contains.
    • It has the longest intracranial course.
    • It is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally.
    • It crosses (decussates) within the brainstem before exiting, meaning that each nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle on the opposite side of the body from where it originated.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 364

choices.text: Anterior Ethmoidal Artery
Greater Palatine Artery
Superior Labial Artery

questions.text: All of the following are Branches of External Carotid Artery supplying Nasal Septum except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior Ethmoidal Artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is indeed the correct answer as the exception among the listed options.
  • It is not a branch of the external carotid artery; rather, it originates from the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • The anterior ethmoidal artery supplies the anterior part of the nasal septum but is not a direct branch of the external carotid artery like the other options listed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Sphenopalatine artery arises from the maxillary artery (external carotid artery) and is also called the artery of epistaxis.

 

Option C: Greater palatine artery arises from maxillary artery (external carotid artery) and supplies the posteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Option D: Septal branches of superior labial artery from facial artery (external carotid artery) supplies the mobile part of nasal septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal artery that supplies the anterosuperior portion of the nasal septum is a branch of ophthalmic artery which arises from the cerebral part of internal carotid artery.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 212

questions.text:
Sequential Arrangement of Auditory Pathway from Periphery to Centre:

 

  1. Cochlear Nerve 
  2. Superior Olivary Nucleus
  3. Medial Geniculate Body
  4. Cochlear Nuclei
  5. Lateral Lemniscus
  6. Inferior Colliculus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-4-2-5-6-3

 

Option B: The auditory pathway transmits sound information from the cochlea in the inner ear to the auditory cortex of the brain.

 

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of structures involved in this pathway is as follows:

 

  1. Cochlear nerve: Sound information is initially converted into electrical signals by hair cells in the cochlea. These signals are then carried by the cochlear nerve, a part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), from the cochlea to the brainstem.
  2. Cochlear nuclei: Upon reaching the brainstem, the fibers of the cochlear nerve synapse in the cochlear nuclei (dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei), which are located at the junction of the pons and medulla.
  3. Superior olivary nucleus: After the cochlear nuclei, some fibers cross to the other side (decussate) and along with uncrossed fibers, project to the superior olivary nucleus in the pons. The superior olivary nucleus is involved in sound localization.
  4. Lateral lemniscus: Axons from the superior olivary nucleus and other nuclei ascend to the midbrain through a tract called the lateral lemniscus.
  5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus fibers synapse in the inferior colliculus, which is an important auditory relay station in the midbrain and is involved in the reflexive responses to sound.
  6. Medial geniculate body: From the inferior colliculus, the pathway continues to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus, which acts as a relay station, further processing auditory information before sending it to the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sequence of Auditory Pathway
  • Cochlear Nerve
  • Cochlear Nucleus
  • Superior Olivary Nucleus
  • Lateral Lemniscus
  • Medial Geniculate Body
  • Auditory Cortex
    • First Order Neuron – Spiral Ganglion
    • Second Order Neuron – Cochlear Nucleus
    • Third Order Neuron – Superior Olivary Nucleus
    • Fourth Order Neuron – Medial Geniculate Body

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 273

questions.text: Tympanic Membrane is supplied by ALL except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial Nerve

 

Option D:

 

  • Nerve supply of tympanic membrane is shown in below image:

 

 

  • The facial nerve during its course within the bony canal inside the middle ear gives rise to two branches-nerve to stapedius and chorda tympani nerve, both do not supply the tympanic membrane. Greater petrosal nerve arises from geniculate ganglion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The lower and posterior part of the cuticular layer of tympanic membrane is supplied by auricular branch of vagus.

 

Option B: The mucous layer of tympanic membrane is supplied by IX nerve via tympanic plexus.

 

Option C: The upper and anterior part of the cuticular layer of the tympanic membrane is supplied by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tympanic membrane, or eardrum, receives its sensory innervation from several cranial nerves due to its complex embryological development. The nerves supplying the tympanic membrane include:

 

  1. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), supplies the anterior and superior portions of the tympanic membrane.
  2. Auricular Branch of the Vagus Nerve (Arnold's Nerve): This branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) supplies the posterior and inferior parts of the tympanic membrane. It can be involved in the cough reflex elicited by ear manipulations.
  3. Tympanic Branch of the Glossopharyngeal Nerve (Jacobson's Nerve): This branch provides innervation to the middle ear cavity, including the medial surface of the tympanic membrane.
  4. These nerves together ensure that the tympanic membrane is well-innervated, allowing it to transmit vibrations caused by sound waves effectively to the ossicles of the middle ear, and also making it sensitive to pain, touch, and temperature.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 280

choices.text: Superior Belly of Omohyoid

questions.text: Muscle innervated by Descendens Hypoglossi?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior Belly of Omohyoid

 

Option B:

 

Superior root of ansa cervicalis is formed by C1 fibres (descendenshypoglossi) which innervates superior belly of omohyoid.

 

 

  • The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by fibers from the cervical plexus, primarily involving the first three cervical spinal nerves (C1, C2, and C3).
  • It is located in the neck, within the carotid sheath, lying superficial to the internal jugular vein and lateral to the carotid artery.
  • The ansa cervicalis provides motor innervation to several infrahyoid muscles, which include the sternohyoid, omohyoid, and sternothyroid muscles.
  • These muscles play crucial roles in swallowing and stabilizing the hyoid bone.
  • The superior root of the ansa cervicalis carries fibers from C1 (and sometimes C2), which travel with the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) briefly before branching off to form the ansa.
  • The inferior root is formed by fibers from C2 and C3. This nerve loop is important in surgical procedures involving the neck and is a key anatomical landmark for head and neck surgeons.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Geniohyoid and thyrohyoid innervated by C1 fibres which travel along with hypoglossal nerve.

 

Option C: Loop of ansa cervicalis innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid and inferior belly of omohyoid.

 

Option D: Mylohyoid innervated by nerve to mylohyoid from inferior alveolar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The descendens hypoglossi, also known as the ansa cervicalis, is a nerve loop that is part of the cervical plexus. It is formed from fibers from the first and second cervical spinal nerves (C1 and C2), with contributions from C1 traveling along the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) before branching off to form the ansa cervicalis.
  • This nerve primarily innervates the infrahyoid muscles, which are muscles located below the hyoid bone and are involved in swallowing and speech. The specific muscles innervated by the descendens hypoglossi (ansa cervicalis) include:
  1. Sternohyoid Muscle: This muscle depresses the hyoid bone after it has been elevated during swallowing.
  2. Omohyoid Muscle: The omohyoid has two bellies (superior and inferior), and its action also depresses the hyoid bone, as well as the larynx, after swallowing.
  3. Sternothyroid Muscle: This muscle depresses the thyroid cartilage and also plays a role in the mechanics of swallowing.

 

The thyrohyoid muscle, although closely related to these muscles, is innervated directly by fibers from the first cervical spinal nerve (C1) that travel with the hypoglossal nerve but do not form part of the ansa cervicalis.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 188

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery at the lateral part of the skull. Postoperative complication of the patient is aspirations without voice change. The nerve involved in this condition supplies which of the following muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Option A:

 

  • The postoperative complication of aspiration without voice change suggests a nerve injury affecting swallowing but not vocal cord function.
  • The nerve involved in this condition is Glossopharyngeal nerve it innervates stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII). While injury to the facial nerve can affect some functions of the face, it is not typically associated with aspiration, as the digastric muscle primarily functions in the opening of the mouth and does not play a direct role in the swallowing process.

 

Option C. The medial pterygoid muscle, innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is a muscle of mastication. Damage to this nerve would primarily affect chewing rather than swallowing or voice, so it is unlikely to cause aspiration without voice change.

 

Option D. The thyropharyngeus muscle, a part of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx, is innervated by branches from the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). Damage to this nerve could lead to impaired swallowing because the inferior constrictor muscle helps in the swallowing mechanism by constricting the pharynx. However, the recurrent laryngeal nerve also innervates the vocal cords, and its damage typically leads to voice changes, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle, which elevates the pharynx during swallowing. Damage to this nerve could potentially contribute to swallowing difficulties. However, the glossopharyngeal nerve primarily affects sensation and taste in the posterior third of the tongue and does not typically lead to aspiration.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve (CN IX) and plays a key role in the sensory and motor functions of the pharynx and back of the tongue.  It is responsible for sensation in the posterior part of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, and the middle ear. It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue. Motor functions include aiding in swallowing and the secretion of saliva from the parotid gland.
  • This nerve originates in the brainstem, specifically in the medulla oblongata. It exits the skull through the jugular foramen before branching to various parts of the throat and tongue.
  • Damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve can lead to a variety of symptoms, including loss of taste in the posterior third of the tongue, difficulty swallowing, loss of gag reflex, and altered sensation in the throat and tongue. Glossopharyngeal neuralgia, a condition characterized by severe pain in areas innervated by this nerve, can also occur.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 405

questions.text: A 58-year-old man who had undergone left-sided pneumonectomy for carcinoma of the bronchus was seen by his thoracic surgeon as a follow-up after the operation. The patient said that he noticed a week ago his left upper eyelid tended to droop slightly when he was tired at the end of the day. On examination it was noted that in addition to the drooping of the left eye, the patient's left pupil was constricted and that his face was slightly flushed on the left side. Further examination revealed that the skin on the left side of the face appeared to be warmer and drier than normal. Palpation of the deep cervical lymph nodes revealed a large hard fixed node just above the left clavicle. Ptosis seen in this case is due to injury:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sympathetic Fibres

 

Option D:

 

  • The clinical presentation of a 58-year-old man post-left-sided pneumonectomy for carcinoma of the bronchus, exhibiting ptosis (drooping of the left upper eyelid), constricted left pupil (miosis), facial flushing, and anhidrosis (reduced sweating) on the left side of the face, along with a large hard fixed node above the left clavicle, suggests a classic case of Horner's syndrome.
  • This is a case of Horner’s syndrome where there is injury to the postganglionic fibres from superior cervical sympathetic ganglion.
  • These sympathetic fibres supply the smooth muscle component of levator palpebrae superioris to cause ptosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Though oculomotor nerve injury can cause paralysis of levator palpebrae superioris and cause ptosis, in this patient presenting with Horner’s syndrome this is not the cause for ptosis.

 

Option B. Facial nerve innervates orbicularis oculi, the contraction of which cause closure of eyes and its injury is not related to ptosis

 

Option C. Parasympathetic fiber involvement could potentially lead to pupil constriction. However, it wouldn't explain the ptosis, facial flushing, and anhidrosis observed in this case. Parasympathetic fibers also don't typically cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Injury to the sympathetic fibers, particularly those in the cervical sympathetic chain, can lead to Horner's syndrome, which is characterized by ptosis, miosis, facial flushing, and anhidrosis on the affected side.
  • This condition can occur as a complication of thoracic surgeries, like pneumonectomy, particularly when the surgery involves structures near the sympathetic chain in the neck and upper chest.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 393,294

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman whose impacted left lower wisdom tooth was surgically removed. The operation lasted about an hour, and the dental surgeon suspected that some nerves might have been bruised during the operation. The patient presented with loss of sensation in the gums of her lower jaw, and her mouth was slightly dry. On examination the taste sensation in the tongue was diminished in the anterior two-thirds but it was normal in the posterior portion. Which among the following nerves has been injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lingual Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • The lingual nerve, which is a branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve.
  • The lingual nerve supplies general sensory fibers to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, the floor of the mouth and the gums of the mandibular teeth.

 

 

  • It carries the chorda tympani nerve, which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The hypoglossal nerve primarily controls all the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus. Injury to the hypoglossal nerve would typically result in tongue muscle weakness or paralysis, affecting tongue movement.

 

Option B. The glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for various functions in the throat and mouth, including taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue. Injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve could result in loss of taste sensation in the posterior portion of the tongue but would not directly affect the sensation in the gums.

 

Option D. The vagus nerve has extensive functions related to the autonomic nervous system and controls various organs in the thoracic and abdominal cavities. It does not play a direct role in taste sensation or sensation in the gums and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and also plays a role in providing sensation to the lower gums and floor of the mouth.Injury to the lingual nerve during dental surgery can result in loss of sensation in the gums and tongue.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 390

choices.text: Patient is not able to whistle due to paralysis of orbicularis oris
Facial nerve lies deep within the parotid gland
Buccinator prevents accumulation of food within vestibule of mouth
Orbicularis oculi is innervated by temporal & zygomatic branch of facial nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old man complained of inability to shut his left eye, difficulty in chewing food inside his mouth and weakness on the same side of his mouth with slight numbness on the left cheek. All these symptoms manifested two weeks prior, following an excisional biopsy of a left facial lump that proved to be a benign parotid tumor. On examination there was an area of mild numbness on the left cheek. Examination of facial muscles revealed paralysis of facial muscles as a result of injury to facial nerve branches that must have happened during the biopsy. The patient was suggested intensive physiotherapy sessions and regular checkups to monitor the progress. Which among the following statements pertaining to the above case is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient is not able to whistle due to paralysis of orbicularis oris

 

Option A:

 

  • This is a typical case of facial palsy.
  • In facial palsy buccinators is paralysed which is known as whistling muscle. Its weakness results in loss of whistling activity not the orbicularis oris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The facial nerve passes through the parotid gland, and surgical procedures involving the parotid gland carry a risk of injury to the facial nerve branches. It lies superficial within the parotid gland, superficial to the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery.

 

Option C. The buccinator muscle is indeed involved in the movement of food during chewing and helps prevent the accumulation of food within the vestibule of the mouth. Contraction of buccinator flattens the cheek against the gums and prevents food accumulation within the vestibule

 

Option D. The orbicularis oculi muscle, which controls eyelid closure, is primarily innervated by the facial nerve, specifically the temporal and zygomatic branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of facial palsy, paralysis of the buccinator muscle, commonly known as the "whistling muscle," occurs.
  • This impairment primarily affects the ability to whistle, as opposed to the orbicularis oris muscle, which is not the primary muscle involved in this activity.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 389

questions.text: A 48-year-old male of moderate built, non-smoker leading a healthy lifestyle presented to OPD with complaints of double vision while walking down the stairs. He also had a similar problem while reading the newspaper. He had no other concerns. Which of the following would be responsible for the patient’ symptoms in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trochlear Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • Lesion to the trochlear nerve will cause paralysis of superior oblique muscle.
  • Contraction of superior oblique muscle will produce intrusion, depression and abduction of the eyeball.
  • In this case patient presents with vertical diplopia which is due to lesion of trochlear nerve

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the eye muscles, including the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, and the inferior oblique muscle. It also controls the levator palpebrae muscle, which raises the eyelid. Since oculomotor nerve supplies all extraocular muscles except lateral rectus & superior oblique, its lesion will produce vertical & horizontal diplopia, ptosis, enlarged and non-reactive pupil

 

Option C. The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Dysfunction in this nerve typically causes horizontal double vision, where the images are side by side, and is most apparent when the patient tries to look towards the side of the affected nerve. Damage to abducens nerve will result in internal squint, as abducens nerve supplies lateral rectus.

 

Option D. The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. While damage to the optic nerve can lead to visual disturbances, it does not typically cause double vision. Instead, it would more likely result in loss of visual acuity or visual field deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye. This muscle primarily helps in downward and inward movement of the eye.
  • Dysfunction of the trochlear nerve can lead to difficulty with downward gaze, particularly when the eye is adducted, which aligns with the patient’s symptoms of double vision while reading or walking downstairs.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 376

choices.text: Internal Laryngeal Nerve
External Laryngeal Nerve
Both A & B
None of the above

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to surgery OPD with complaints of a swollen neck. She had first noticed the swelling two months ago and it had been increasing in size since then. She also had complaints of breathlessness. On examination, a solitary swelling of firm consistency was found on the left side of the larynx and trachea. The small mass was not attached to the skin and there were no changes to the overlying skin. The swelling moved upward with swallowing. Further tests showed that the mass was a carcinoma of the thyroid gland. The mass was surgically removed. Post-operatively, the surgeon carefully ensured that the patient was speaking properly to test which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External Laryngeal Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • External laryngeal nerve is a motor to the cricothyroid muscle which is a tensor of the vocal cord. Since it accompanies the superior thyroid artery it can be injured. Injury to this nerve can result in weakness of voice

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve), provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords. While damage to this nerve can affect sensation in the larynx, it is not typically associated with changes in the voice. Thus, speaking would not be an effective test for injury to this nerve. Internal laryngeal nerve is entirely sensory, it pierces the thyrohyoid membrane and supplies the larynx above the level of vocal cords

 

Option C. While both nerves are important, the internal laryngeal nerve is more involved in sensation rather than vocalization. Therefore, speaking tests are more specifically directed towards assessing the function of the external laryngeal nerve.

 

Option D. This option is incorrect because one of the above-mentioned nerves, specifically the external laryngeal nerve, is indeed tested by assessing speech post-operatively in thyroid surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • External laryngeal nerve, another branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, innervates the cricothyroid muscle. This muscle adjusts tension in the vocal cords, which is crucial for speech modulation, especially for high-pitched sounds.
  •  Injury to this nerve can lead to a hoarse voice or difficulty in voice modulation. Testing the patient's ability to speak, particularly in varying pitches, is a direct way to assess the integrity of the external laryngeal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 408

choices.text: It arises from midbrain at level of Inferior Colliculus
Carries Preganglionic Parasympathetic fibres
Has the longest Subarachnoid course
Passes through Dorello’s canal

questions.text: Which of the following statement true regarding the cranial nerve involved for the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibres

 

Option B:

 

The image given is oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The preganglionic parasympathetic fibres traversing oculomotor nerve arises from Edinger Westphal nucleus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The oculomotor nerve arises from the midbrain, but at the level of the superior colliculus, not the inferior colliculus.

 

Option C. While the oculomotor nerve does have a significant subarachnoid course, it is not the longest. The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is often considered to have the longest intradural course of the cranial nerves.

 

Option D. It is the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) that passes through Dorello’s canal, not the oculomotor nerve. The oculomotor nerve exits the brainstem between the midbrain and pons and passes between the two layers of the tentorium cerebelli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion. These fibers are responsible for controlling the constrictor muscles of the iris (pupillary constriction) and the ciliary muscles of the lens. In oculomotor nerve palsy, these parasympathetic fibers can be affected, leading to pupil dilation (mydriasis) and loss of accommodation.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 373

choices.text: Opens into the floor of mouth into frenulum linguae
It arises from anterior division of mandibular nerve
Belongs to somatic efferent column
It is the first branch from external carotid artery

questions.text: Identify the true statement for the pointed structures:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Belongs to somatic efferent column

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

A-Wharton’s duct

 

B-Lingual nerve

 

C-Hypoglossal nerve

 

D-Lingual artery

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Wharton's duct opens into the floor of mouth on sublingual papillae on either side of frenulum linguae.

 

Option B: Lingual nerve arises from posterior division of mandibular nerve

 

Option D. Lingual artery course divided by hyoglossus muscle into 3 parts. Superior thyroid artery is the first branch from external carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is entirely motor (somatic efferent column) and supplies all muscles of tongue except Palatoglossus

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 149

questions.text: Injury of which of the following nerve causes of drooping of shoulder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Option B:

 

  • Spinal accessory nerve innervates trapezius and sternocleidomastoid. Injury to it results in drooping of shoulder (paralysis of trapezius)

 

The marked structures in the given image are:

 

  1. Lesser occipital Nerve

  2. Spinal accessory Nerve

  3. Great auricular Nerve

  4. Transverse Cervical Cutaneous Nerve

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lesser occipital nerve, from ventral of C2 hooks around spinal accessory nerve and ascends to supply upper part of cranial surface of auricle and skin behind auricle.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve supplies skin over angle of mandible, skin over mastoid process and most of the auricle.

 

Option D. Transverse cervical cutaneous nerve passes deep to external jugular vein to reach anterior border of sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spinal accessory nerve innervates trapezius and sternocleidomastoid. Injury to it results in drooping of shoulder (paralysis of trapezius)

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 199

choices.text: Inferior Alveolar Nerve
Nerve to Mylohyoid

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoglossal Nerve

 

Option B:

 

The pointed structure is Hypoglossal nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve lies in intimate relation to submandibular duct.

 

Option C. Inferior alveolar nerve from posterior division of mandibular nerve passes through the mandibular foramen.

 

Option D. Nerve to mylohyoid arises from inferior alveolar nerve before it enters the mandibular foramen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypoglossal nerve that lies on the surface of hyoglossus in digastric triangle accompanied by venae comitantes

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg No. 89

choices.text: It is the Cranial Nerve with longest Intradural Course
It has Parasympathetic Component
It undergoes decussation before innervating the target
It has the longest Intraosseous course

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the cranial nerve injured in the clinical condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It undergoes decussation before innervating the target

 

Option C:

 

  • Right trochlear nerve palsy in the given image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abducens nerve has the longest intradural course and is also involved in raised increased intracranial pressure.

 

Option B. Cranial nerve with General visceral efferent fibres/preganglionic parasympathetic fibres include-III, VII, IX and X.

 

Option D. Facial nerve has the longest intraosseous course.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that exits from dorsal aspect of brainstem and decussates with nerve of opposite side in the superior medullary velum.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 376

choices.text: Loss of accommodation

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cranial nerve palsy shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal Strabismus

 

Option C:

 

  • The nerve injured in this condition is Oculomotor nerve.
  • Internal strabismus occurs due to injury of VI cranial nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis is a common symptom of oculomotor nerve palsy. The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which lifts the eyelid. When this nerve is damaged, this muscle fails to function properly, resulting in ptosis.

 

Option B. Mydriasis can occur in oculomotor nerve palsy. The parasympathetic fibers of the oculomotor nerve innervate the sphincter pupillae muscle, which constricts the pupil. Damage to these fibers can lead to an inability to constrict the pupil, causing mydriasis.

 

Option D. Loss of accommodation is generally not a symptom of oculomotor nerve palsy. The ciliary muscle, responsible for accommodation, is innervated by parasympathetic fibers that travel with the oculomotor nerve. However, these fibers are less commonly affected in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internal strabismus, or esotropia, is a condition where one eye turns inward.
  • This cannot be a result of oculomotor nerve palsy. Strabismus is caused by sixth nerve damage (Abducent nerve). When these muscles are weakened due to nerve damage, it can cause the eye to deviate inward, resulting in internal strabismus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 256.

D supplies skin over the cheek
A is supplied by Buccal Branch of Mandibular Nerve
E&D causes depression of Mandible

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the above image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is supplied by Buccal Branch of Mandibular Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • It is innervated by a buccal branch of the mandibular nerve.

 

The structure marked in the given image:

 

  • A is the mucous membrane of the vestibule of the mouth.
  • B is buccinator muscle
  • D is the buccal branch of the facial nerve.
  • E is the masseter muscle

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Masseter is innervated by mandibular nerve & buccinator by buccal branch of facial nerve.

 

Option B. Upper buccal branch supplies the muscles of upper lip and lower buccal nerve supplies buccinator.

 

Option D. Masseter causes elevation of mandible at temporomandibular joint

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mucous membrane of the vestibule of the mouth. It is innervated by a buccal branch of the mandibular nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 80

questions.text: Which of the following two are innervated by the same nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C & D

 

Option C:

 

  • Medial pterygoid & Masseter: Both are innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

 

The marked structure in the given image:

 

  1. Trapezius
  2. Sternocleidomastoid
  3. Medial pterygoid
  4. Masseter

 

Explanation:

 

  • Trapezius innervated by spinal accessory nerve.
  • Sternocleidomastoid innervated by spinal accessory nerve
  • Medial pterygoid is innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve
  • Masseter is also supplied by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Medial pterygoid & Masseter: Both are innervated by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 77

questions.text: Cranial Nerve involved in this syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) VII

 

Option B: The Cranial Nerve involved in the above condition is Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome which is characterised by vesicles over conchal region of the auricle and Bell’s palsy due to reactivation of varicella zoster virus in geniculate ganglion of facial nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Auriculotemporal nerve, branch from posterior division of mandibular nerve from trigeminal nerve supplies the auricle -part of tragus, helix, antihelix.

 

Option C: Vestibulocochlear nerve enters through internal acoustic meatus and is concerned with equilibrium and hearing.

 

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve through its tympanic branch supplies middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome which is characterised by vesicles over conchal region of the auricle and Bell’s palsy due to reactivation of varicella zoster virus in geniculate ganglion of facial nerve.
  • Facial nerve has no direct cutaneous branch but through its communications with the vagus nerve-Alderman’s nerve -the only cutaneous branch of vagus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 401

choices.text: Nucleus Tractus Solitarius
Inferior Salivatory Nucleus
Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following nucleus is not related to the Facial Nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior Salivatory Nucleus

 

Option B: The inferior salivatory nucleus gives rise to the preganglionic parasympathetic fibres that pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve and its tympanic branch to supply the parotid gland.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The nucleus tractus solitarius is related to multiple cranial nerves, including the Facial nerve. It is involved in processing visceral sensory information and is associated with various functions, including taste perception, which is transmitted by the Facial nerve. It receives afferents from VII, IX and X

 

Option C: Spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve receives pain temperature sensation from face. Alderman's nerve, the only cutaneous branch of Vagus communicates with facial nerve and through this communication facial nerve receives cutaneous sensation from auricle and relays in upper part of spinal nucleus of trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D: Lacrimatory nucleus of facial nerve provides the preganglionic parasympathetic fibres for lacrimal gland. It is involved in controlling lacrimation (tear production) and salivation through parasympathetic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior salivatory nucleus is related to the Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), not the Facial nerve. It is responsible for parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 393

choices.text: Anterior Wall of External Meatus

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a painful rash on her right ear, right-sided facial weakness, and a sensation of spinning when moving her head. She also reports a decrease in hearing on the affected side and a metallic taste in her mouth. On examination, vesicular lesions are noted on the ear, and she is unable to close her right eye or lift her right corner of the mouth. The diagnosis of Ramsay Hunt syndrome is considered. Given the patient's presentation, in which part of the pinna of the ear are the vesicular lesions most likely to be found in Ramsay Hunt syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conchae

 

Option D:

 

 

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as herpes zoster oticus, is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve.
  • The syndrome is characterized by a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the ear or oral mucosa. The presence of vesicles on the conchae, or the hollow part of the external ear near the auditory canal, is a hallmark of the syndrome and helps differentiate it from Bell's palsy, which does not typically involve a rash.
  • The conchae are the most common site for these vesicles in Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which corresponds with the distribution of the sensory fibers of the facial nerve affected by the virus.
  • The involvement of the facial nerve also leads to facial weakness or paralysis on the affected side, and the virus can affect the vestibulocochlear nerve, leading to vertigo (spinning sensation) and hearing loss.
  • The presence of vesicles in the conchae, along with the neurological symptoms, is a key diagnostic clue in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Lobule, Helix, Antihelix, Posterior part of Lateral Surface and most of cranial surface of auricle is innervated by Great auricular nerve.

 

Option B: Anterior wall and roof of external meatus is innervated by auriculotemporal nerve.

 

Option C: Tragus, crus of helix and adjoining area of helix is innervated by auriculotemporal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conchae of the auricle and the posterior wall and roof of external auditory canal is innervated by the auricular branch of vagus nerve which communicates with facial nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 401

questions.text: Muscle of Mastication innervated by Trunk of Mandibular Nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medial Pterygoid

 

Option B:

 

  • Nerve to medial pterygoid innevated the medial pterygoid muscle.
  • Nerve to the medial pterygoid is a branch of the Mandibular Nerve (V3), which is the Third Division of the Trigeminal Nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • This nerve innervates the medial pterygoid muscle, which is one of the muscles of mastication.
  • The medial pterygoid muscle is involved in the elevation of the mandible (closing the mouth) and helps in the side-to-side movement of the jaw.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Masseter is innervated by the anterior division of mandibular nerve and is strong elevator of mandible.

 

Option C: Lateral Pterygoid is innervated by the anterior division of mandibular nerve and is a depressor of mandible.

 

Option D: Temporalis is innervated by the anterior division of mandibular nerve and its posterior fibres are retractors of mandible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trunk of the mandibular nerve gives rise to nerve to medial pterygoid that innervates medial pterygoid and also tensor tympani, tensor palatini.
  • Nervous spinosus also arises from the trunk.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 102

choices.text: Ascending Pharyngeal Artery
Middle Meningeal Artery
Greater Palatine Artery

questions.text: Blood Supply to Facial Nerve are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Greater Palatine Artery

 

Option C: Blood supply to facial nerve is from Middle meningeal artery, Stylomastoid artery and ascending pharyngeal artery.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: True. The ascending pharyngeal artery, one of the branches of the external carotid artery, contributes to the blood supply of the facial nerve, particularly in its intracranial part. The ascending pharyngeal artery supplies the lower part of the nerve near its exit from the skull through the stylomastoid foramen, as well as the adjacent areas.

 

Option B: True. The middle meningeal artery, another branch of the maxillary artery (which is itself a branch of the external carotid artery), also contributes to the vascular supply of the facial nerve. Specifically, it supplies the facial nerve within the facial canal, particularly in the region of the geniculate ganglion.

 

Option D: True. The stylomastoid artery, often a branch of the posterior auricular artery (which is a branch of the external carotid artery), or directly from the external carotid artery itself, is a key supplier of blood to the facial nerve. It enters the facial canal through the stylomastoid foramen and supplies the facial nerve, particularly in the region where the nerve exits the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

False. The greater palatine artery, which arises from the maxillary artery, primarily supplies the hard palate and the nasal cavity but does not contribute to the blood supply of the facial nerve. This artery is more involved in the vascular supply to the oral and nasal mucosa and the periodontal ligament.

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 321

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of tobacco use presents to the clinic complaining of persistent sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a notable pain in his left ear for the past two months. He denies any hearing loss but mentions the ear pain intensifies when he swallows. Physical examination reveals a unilateral mass at the base of his tongue. No abnormalities are noted in the external ear canal or tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for the referred ear pain this patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal Nerve

 

Option C: In this case referred pain to ear is via IX nerve

 

 

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, the oropharynx, and the upper pharynx, including the area at the base of the tongue where the carcinoma is located in this patient.
  • Additionally, it carries sensory fibers from the middle ear and the adjacent area, which can lead to the phenomenon of referred pain.
  • Referred pain occurs when pain originating from one location is perceived in a different area, usually within the same sensory distribution of a nerve.
  • In this case, the pain from the carcinoma at the base of the tongue is perceived in the ear due to the common innervation by the glossopharyngeal nerve. This is a classic presentation in head and neck pathologies, especially in carcinomas of the oropharyngeal region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) is primarily a motor nerve responsible for controlling the movements of the tongue. It does not carry sensory or pain fibers, so it would not be involved in the referral of pain to the ear in carcinoma of the base of the tongue.

 

Option B: While the vagus nerve does have extensive sensory, motor, and autonomic functions, and does innervate parts of the ear, it is less directly involved in the sensation of pain referred from the base of the tongue to the ear in the context of carcinoma.

 

Option D: The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), provides general somatic sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not innervate the base of the tongue where the carcinoma is located, nor does it innervate the ear, so it would not be responsible for referring pain to the ear in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • General sensation from posterior 1/3 tongue - IX nerve
  • In cases of carcinoma at the base of the tongue, pain can be referred to the ear through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX): This is the correct answer.

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, the oropharynx, and the tonsils.
  • It also carries sensory fibers from the middle ear and the pharyngotympanic (Eustachian) tube.
  • In cases of carcinoma at the base of the tongue, pain can be referred along the sensory pathways of the glossopharyngeal nerve to the ear, leading to otalgia (ear pain).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 139

choices.text: Internal Nasal Cavity
Duramater of Anterior Cranial Fossa

questions.text: Anterior Ethmoidal Nerve supplies ALL Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary Sinus

 

Option A:

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal nerve is a continuation of the nasociliary nerve.
  • Maxillary sinus is supplied by branches from posterior ethmoidal nerve and orbital branches from pterygopalatine ganglion.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the anterior part of the nasal septum and the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It provides sensory innervation to these areas, contributing to the sensation of the internal nasal cavity.

 

Option C: The anterior ethmoidal nerve also gives off a meningeal branch that supplies the dura mater of the anterior cranial fossa. This is an example of the trigeminal nerve's extensive role in providing sensory innervation to the dura mater.

 

Option D: The anterior ethmoidal nerve indeed supplies the anterior ethmoidal cells. These are air cells within the ethmoid bone that are part of the paranasal sinus system, and they receive sensory innervation from this nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1), has several areas of innervation, but there are specific regions it does and does not supply.
  • The anterior ethmoidal nerve does not supply the maxillary sinus. The maxillary sinus is primarily innervated by branches of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), specifically the superior alveolar nerves and the infraorbital nerve, which are all part of the second division of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 364
